results.title: Sea dream
results.creator_credit: Ellen Besen, Margaret Pettigrew and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Children, like adults, have days that go wrong. This film shows how one little girl overcomes the day’s frustrations by diving into an underwater fantasy where she spends time with her friend, the lady octopus. After playing many wonderful games together, the little girl re-enters the world of reality, feeling fine and refreshed. Animation by Bill Speers. (Awards: New York, Ottawa)

results.title: Scum (D)
results.creator_credit: Alan Clarke, Clive Parsons, David Belling, Berwick Street Films and Boyd's Company
results.brief_description: Scum was originally made for television but banned because of its confronting content. Ray Winstone plays Carlin, an under-age offender sent from reform school to Borstal prison for assaulting a prison guard. In Borstal institutionalised violence is a way of life: the guards use it against the boys, the stronger boys against the younger boys. This is a bleak disturbing world of masculine aggression and hate, a racist world where black and white prisoners form separate ‘communities’, and where rape and physical coercion are accepted as currency. ‘Scum’, however, is not exploitative. The filmmakers’ anger is firmly directed to the hypocritical and sanctimonious authorities which allow the prison system to function through brutality rather than through justice. By the end of the film, in which we have seen a young vulnerable boy kill himself rather than continue the endless cycle of brutalisation, we come to understand that the prison system as portrayed in this film damages everyone: prisoners, guards, and finally ourselves. The attempts to ban this stark social-realist work and the hysteria mounted against its representation of youth offenders speaks volumes about the unsettling truths it forces us to comprehend.

results.title: Scrubbers
results.creator_credit: Mai Zetterling, Don Boyd and HandMade Films
results.brief_description: Swedish director Mai Zetterling filmed this tense and realistic drama set in Borstal Women’s Goal using a cast of mostly unknown young actors. The film powerfully portrays the dehumanising experiences the mostly young offenders undergo in prison but it does so without resorting to exploitation of the women or a glorification of violence. Instead Zetterling focuses on the friendships formed by the women within prison. “Scrubbers” is unavoidably confronting and disturbing - but it is also a prison film with a refreshing sense of dignity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mai Zetterling, Don Boyd and HandMade Films

results.title: Scrapbook of 1922
results.creator_credit: Leslie Bailey, Peter Baylis and Pathé Frères
results.brief_description: An historical survey of the year 1922; aftermath of World War I; payment of reparations by Germany; German inflation and the rise of a new leader from Munich; Black Shirts marched on Rome; Irish Free State came into existence independent of the British Crown; de Valera and the Civil War in Dublin; Smyrna destroyed in the war between Greece and Turkey; President Harding’s appeal for a return to “normalcy”; British politicians of the day were David Lloyd George, Ramsay MacDonald, Bonar Law and Winston Churchill; the popular sportsmen were Jack Hobbs and Jack Dempsey; the “ladies” took up cricket; Princess Mary was married in Westminster Abbey; the Atlantic crossing was made from east to west; radio broadcasting began from 2LO Marconi House; night-life boomed; theatres billed Stanley Lupino, Gertrude Lawrence, Tom Walls, and cinemas introduced a new star: “Felix the Cat”.

results.title: Political and legal systems
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
Looks at local, state and federal governments as well as the various law courts to show how Australia has adapted the English laws of Westminster. Uses archival footage and includes segments with Malcolm Fraser and Bill Hayden.

results.title: Scientific and medical research
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
An overview of current scientific and medical research in Australia. Looks briefly at space tracking stations, interscan, solar energy, medical technology, nuclear medicine, microsurgery and the invitro fertilisation program. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Culture and recreation
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson, Film Australia and Motion Picture Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A non-narrated montage of images showing aspects of culture and recreation in Australia, interspersed with some historic footage. Shows sport, dance, historic buildings, the Sydney Opera House, opera performances and festivals. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.creator_credit: David Eady, Children's Film Foundation and Eady-Barnes Productions

results.title: Mining
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Johnson and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A detailed statement of Australia’s massive mining developments in the eighties - tin, coal, bauxite, iron ore as well as the production of the more rare metals such as gold, silver and uranium. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.
